name: Hydrogen
fun_fact: The most abundant element in the universe — stars are mostly hydrogen!

name: Helium
fun_fact: Helium is the only element that cannot be solidified at normal pressure.

name: Lithium
fun_fact: Lithium is so light it floats on water — and reacts with it!

name: Beryllium
fun_fact: Beryllium is extremely rigid — used in aerospace parts and X-ray windows.

name: Boron
fun_fact: Boron is used to make Pyrex glass — it can handle extreme heat without breaking.

name: Carbon
fun_fact: Carbon forms more compounds than any other element — the basis of all life!

name: Nitrogen
fun_fact: 78% of the air you breathe is nitrogen — but your body can't use it directly.

name: Oxygen
fun_fact: Oxygen makes up 21% of our atmosphere and nearly half of the Earth's crust by mass.

name: Fluorine
fun_fact: Fluorine is the most electronegative element — it attacks nearly everything!

name: Neon
fun_fact: Neon glows bright orange-red in signs — each noble gas has its own unique glow color.

name: Sodium
fun_fact: Sodium explodes violently when it touches water!

name: Magnesium
fun_fact: Magnesium burns with a brilliant white flame so bright it can damage your eyes.

name: Aluminum
fun_fact: Aluminum is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.

name: Silicon
fun_fact: Silicon Valley is named after silicon — the foundation of all modern electronics.

name: Phosphorus
fun_fact: White phosphorus glows in the dark and ignites spontaneously in air.

name: Sulfur
fun_fact: Sulfur smells like rotten eggs — volcanoes release it in huge quantities.

name: Chlorine
fun_fact: Chlorine was used as a chemical weapon in WWI — it's toxic in gas form.

name: Argon
fun_fact: Argon makes up about 1% of Earth's atmosphere — the third most common gas.

name: Potassium
fun_fact: Potassium reacts so violently with water it can catch fire!

name: Calcium
fun_fact: Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body — in your bones and teeth!

name: Scandium
fun_fact: Scandium is so rare it wasn't found in nature until 1879 — predicted by the periodic table first!

name: Titanium
fun_fact: Titanium is as strong as steel but 45% lighter — and completely biocompatible.

name: Vanadium
fun_fact: Vanadium steel is used in crankshafts and gears — Henry Ford loved it.

name: Chromium
fun_fact: Chromium gives rubies their red color and is what makes stainless steel stainless.

name: Manganese
fun_fact: Manganese nodules litter the ocean floor — a vast untapped resource.

name: Iron
fun_fact: Iron is the most used metal on Earth and the core of our planet is mostly iron.

name: Cobalt
fun_fact: Cobalt blue is one of the oldest pigments — used in ancient Egyptian glass.

name: Nickel
fun_fact: Nickel coins aren't actually made of much nickel — only 25% in US nickels.

name: Copper
fun_fact: Copper was the first metal ever used by humans — over 10,000 years ago.

name: Zinc
fun_fact: Zinc galvanizes iron to prevent rust — most galvanized steel has a zinc coating.

name: Gallium
fun_fact: Gallium melts in your hand — its melting point is just 29.7°C.

name: Germanium
fun_fact: Mendeleev predicted germanium's existence 15 years before it was discovered!

name: Arsenic
fun_fact: Arsenic was the poison of choice in medieval Europe — tasteless and hard to detect.

name: Selenium
fun_fact: Selenium was named after Selene, the Greek goddess of the Moon.

name: Bromine
fun_fact: Bromine is one of only two elements that is liquid at room temperature.

name: Krypton
fun_fact: The international metre was once defined by the wavelength of krypton light.

name: Rubidium
fun_fact: Rubidium ignites spontaneously in air and reacts explosively with water.

name: Strontium
fun_fact: Strontium gives fireworks their brilliant crimson red color.

name: Yttrium
fun_fact: Yttrium is named after Ytterby, a small village in Sweden near a famous mineral mine.

name: Zirconium
fun_fact: Zirconium is used in nuclear reactors because it barely absorbs neutrons.

name: Niobium
fun_fact: Niobium is used in superconducting magnets for MRI machines and particle accelerators.

name: Molybdenum
fun_fact: Molybdenum has one of the highest melting points of any metal — 2623°C.

name: Technetium
fun_fact: Technetium was the first artificially produced element — it doesn't exist naturally on Earth.

name: Ruthenium
fun_fact: Ruthenium is one of the rarest metals on Earth — a platinum group metal.

name: Rhodium
fun_fact: Rhodium is the rarest and most expensive precious metal — rarer than gold or platinum.

name: Palladium
fun_fact: Palladium can absorb 900 times its own volume of hydrogen gas.

name: Silver
fun_fact: Silver has the highest electrical conductivity of any element.

name: Cadmium
fun_fact: Cadmium poisoning caused a mass illness in Japan called Itai-itai disease.

name: Indium
fun_fact: Indium makes a high-pitched 'cry' when bent — a property called tin cry.

name: Tin
fun_fact: The Bronze Age was powered by bronze — an alloy of copper and tin.

name: Antimony
fun_fact: Ancient Egyptians used antimony sulfide as kohl eyeliner — a toxic beauty product!

name: Tellurium
fun_fact: Even tiny amounts of tellurium cause a persistent garlic-like odor in breath and sweat.

name: Iodine
fun_fact: Iodine turns violet when vaporized — the only element named for its color (Greek: iodes).

name: Xenon
fun_fact: Xenon ion propulsion drives spacecraft — it's the fuel of deep space probes.

name: Caesium
fun_fact: Caesium atomic clocks are so precise they lose only one second every 300 million years.

name: Barium
fun_fact: Barium sulfate is given to patients before X-rays — it makes soft tissues visible.

name: Lanthanum
fun_fact: Lanthanum gives camera lenses and telescope optics their clarity.

name: Cerium
fun_fact: Cerium is the most abundant rare earth element — and it's self-cleaning in catalysts.

name: Praseodymium
fun_fact: Praseodymium makes yellow-green glass for welding goggles.

name: Neodymium
fun_fact: Neodymium magnets are the strongest permanent magnets — used in every electric motor.

name: Promethium
fun_fact: Promethium has no stable isotopes — it was the last element to be discovered in nature.

name: Samarium
fun_fact: Samarium-cobalt magnets work at higher temperatures than neodymium magnets.

name: Europium
fun_fact: Europium phosphors make euro banknotes glow under UV light — an anti-counterfeiting measure.

name: Gadolinium
fun_fact: Gadolinium contrast agents light up tumors in MRI scans.

name: Terbium
fun_fact: Terbium changes size when placed in a magnetic field — a property called magnetostriction.

name: Dysprosium
fun_fact: Every electric vehicle motor contains dysprosium — it's critical for modern clean energy.

name: Holmium
fun_fact: Holmium has the strongest magnetic moment of any element.

name: Erbium
fun_fact: Erbium amplifies signals in fiber optic cables — it's what makes the internet fast.

name: Thulium
fun_fact: Thulium is so rare that most people will never encounter it in any form.

name: Ytterbium
fun_fact: Ytterbium atomic clocks may be the most precise timekeepers ever created.

name: Lutetium
fun_fact: Lutetium is the last and hardest of the lanthanides — and one of the most expensive.

name: Hafnium
fun_fact: Hafnium is always found mixed with zirconium — they're nearly impossible to separate.

name: Tantalum
fun_fact: Tantalum is used in capacitors in your phone — conflict over it funds wars in the Congo.

name: Tungsten
fun_fact: Tungsten has the highest melting point of any metal — 3422°C. Old light bulb filaments were tungsten.

name: Rhenium
fun_fact: Rhenium was the last stable element discovered — in 1925. Only 50 tonnes are produced annually.

name: Osmium
fun_fact: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element — twice as heavy as lead.

name: Iridium
fun_fact: The K-Pg boundary clay layer (dinosaur extinction) is rich in iridium — from a meteorite impact.

name: Platinum
fun_fact: All the platinum ever mined would fit in an average living room.

name: Gold
fun_fact: Gold is so malleable that 1 gram can be beaten into a sheet covering 1 square metre.

name: Mercury
fun_fact: Mercury is the only metal that's liquid at room temperature — and it's highly toxic.

name: Thallium
fun_fact: Thallium was once used as rat poison and a murder weapon — it's colorless, odorless, and tasteless.

name: Lead
fun_fact: Roman water pipes were made of lead — some historians blame lead poisoning for Rome's fall.

name: Bismuth
fun_fact: Bismuth forms beautiful hopper crystals that look like tiny staircases of color.

name: Polonium
fun_fact: Polonium was discovered by Marie Curie, named for her homeland Poland. It's deadly radioactive.

name: Astatine
fun_fact: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element — only ~28g exists in Earth's crust at any time.

name: Radon
fun_fact: Radon seeps from the ground into basements and is the second leading cause of lung cancer.

name: Francium
fun_fact: Francium is so rare and unstable, only ~20 atoms are thought to exist on Earth at any moment.
real_world_uses: research only — too rare and unstable for practical use

name: Radium
fun_fact: Radium paint was used on watch dials — workers who licked their brushes died of radiation poisoning.

name: Actinium
fun_fact: Actinium glows blue in the dark due to the ionization it causes in surrounding air.

name: Thorium
fun_fact: Thorium could power thorium reactors that are safer and produce less waste than uranium.

name: Protactinium
fun_fact: Protactinium is one of the rarest and most toxic elements — handling it requires extreme care.

name: Uranium
fun_fact: Uranium was used as orange glass dye before anyone knew it was radioactive.

name: Neptunium
fun_fact: Neptunium was the first transuranium element ever synthesized — in 1940.

name: Plutonium
fun_fact: Plutonium can warm itself to touch just from its own radioactive decay.

name: Americium
fun_fact: Americium-241 is in smoke detectors — a tiny amount keeps you safe every day.

name: Curium
fun_fact: Curium was named after Marie and Pierre Curie — the power couple of radioactivity.

name: Berkelium
fun_fact: Only a few micrograms of berkelium have ever been produced — it's extraordinarily rare.
real_world_uses: research only — used to synthesize heavier elements

name: Californium
fun_fact: Californium-252 is used to start up nuclear reactors and treat certain cancers.

name: Einsteinium
fun_fact: Einsteinium was first found in the fallout of the first hydrogen bomb test in 1952.

name: Fermium
fun_fact: Fermium has never been seen with the naked eye — only picogram quantities exist.

name: Mendelevium
fun_fact: Named after Mendeleev, who created the periodic table — fitting for element 101.

name: Nobelium
fun_fact: Named after Alfred Nobel, inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Prize.

name: Lawrencium
fun_fact: Lawrencium ends the actinide series — named after Ernest Lawrence, inventor of the cyclotron.

name: Rutherfordium
fun_fact: Named after Ernest Rutherford, who discovered the atomic nucleus.

name: Dubnium
fun_fact: Dubnium was a Cold War controversy — both the US and USSR claimed to have discovered it.

name: Seaborgium
fun_fact: Glenn Seaborg is the only person to have an element named after them while still alive.

name: Bohrium
fun_fact: Named after Niels Bohr, the father of quantum mechanics and atomic structure.

name: Hassium
fun_fact: Hassium is predicted to behave like osmium — but only a few atoms have ever been made.

name: Meitnerium
fun_fact: Named after Lise Meitner, physicist who helped discover nuclear fission but was denied the Nobel Prize.

name: Darmstadtium
fun_fact: Darmstadtium exists for only milliseconds — one of the shortest-lived known elements.

name: Roentgenium
fun_fact: Named after Wilhelm Röntgen, discoverer of X-rays.

name: Copernicium
fun_fact: Copernicium may actually be a gas at room temperature — unique among metals.

name: Nihonium
fun_fact: Nihonium was discovered by Japan — the first element found in Asia. Named after Nihon (Japan).

name: Flerovium
fun_fact: Flerovium may behave more like a noble gas than a metal due to relativistic effects.

name: Moscovium
fun_fact: Named after Moscow Oblast, where the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research is located.

name: Livermorium
fun_fact: Named after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.

name: Tennessine
fun_fact: Tennessine is named after Tennessee — home to Vanderbilt, the University of Tennessee, and Oak Ridge Lab.

name: Oganesson
fun_fact: Oganesson is the heaviest element ever made — and may not behave like a noble gas at all.
